datalanguage.meta_description: Kitchen apron. Killer whale design. Blue. 100% cotton. Dimensions: 24" x 12". Made in Canada.
datalanguage.meta_keywords: Bill Helin Killer Whale Apron, Aprons, SKU: 53-53-613, Bill, Helin, killer, whale, kitchen, cotton, apron, Compositions: Cotton,
datalanguage.name: Bill Helin Killer Whale Apron
datalanguage.description:
Tsimshian native artist Bill Helin enjoys a very rewarding career as a creative gold engraver, painter, woodcarver, and book illustrator. He loves to paint mythological images to educate people on the history of the Tsimshian nation and the many stories passed down through his ancestors. His greatest passion however is to spiritually represent and bond individuals together through the use of native Life Crest symbols.

The killer whale is the lord of the oceans and a symbol of long life.  It is believed that great chiefs turn into killer whales when they pass on into the nether world.
datalanguage.description_short: Kitchen apron. Killer whale design. Blue. 100% cotton. Dimensions: 24" x 12". Made in Canada.

datalanguage.meta_description: Tablier de cuisine, motif de l' épaulard. Bleu. 100% coton. Dimensions: 24" x 12". Fait au canada.
datalanguage.meta_keywords: Bill Helin Tablier Épaulard, Tabliers, SKU: 53-53-613, , Composition: Coton,
datalanguage.name: Bill Helin Tablier Épaulard
datalanguage.description: Graveur, peintre, sculpteur sur bois et illustrateur de livres, l'artiste Bill Helin aime peindre des images mythologiques pour instruire les peuples sur l'histoire de la nation Tsimshian et les nombreuses histoires transmises par ses ancêtres. L'épaulard est le roi des océans et un symbole de longévité. Il est dit dans la légende que les Grands Chefs sont réincarnés en épaulards afin de protéger nos mers.
datalanguage.description_short: Tablier de cuisine, motif de l' épaulard. Bleu. 100% coton. Dimensions: 24" x 12". Fait au canada.

datalanguage.description:
Tsimshian native artist Bill Helin enjoys a very rewarding career as a creative gold engraver, painter, woodcarver, and book illustrator. He loves to paint mythological images to educate people on the history of the Tsimshian nation and the many stories passed down through his ancestors. His greatest passion however is to spiritually represent and bond individuals together through the use of native Life Crest symbols.

The Frog is the voice of the people, especially in our family. He strives for family unity, is one who teaches by example and is sometimes a symbol of innocence. The frog is more 'us' and 'we' and less 'I'.

datalanguage.meta_description: Kitchen apron. Hummingbird design. Black, blue and white. Dimensions: 24" x 12". 100% cotton. Made in Canada.
datalanguage.meta_keywords: Bill Helin Hummingbird Apron, Aprons, SKU: 53-53-554, Bill, Helin, kitchen, apron, hummingbirg, Compositions: Cotton,
datalanguage.name: Bill Helin Hummingbird Apron
datalanguage.description:
Tsimshian native artist Bill Helin enjoys a very rewarding career as a creative gold engraver, painter, woodcarver, and book illustrator. He loves to paint mythological images to educate people on the history of the Tsimshian nation and the many stories passed down through his ancestors. His greatest passion however is to spiritually represent and bond individuals together through the use of native Life Crest symbols.

The Tsimshian believe the Hummingbird to be a joyful messenger and mysterious traveler. If he appears during a time of great sorrow and pain, healing will soon follow. He also symbolizes the fragility of nature and all living things. This symbol is often used in gifts between lovers, for wedding rings, on a bracelet or any piece of jewellery - it says you are wished joy, healing and love. The Hummingbird also tells the receiver they bring joy to the giver's life.
datalanguage.description_short: Kitchen apron. Hummingbird design. Black, blue and white. Dimensions: 24" x 12". 100% cotton. Made in Canada.

datalanguage.meta_title: Bill Helin Hummingbird Embroidered Tea Towel
datalanguage.name: Bill Helin Hummingbird Embroidered Tea Towel
datalanguage.description:
Tsimshian native artist Bill Helin enjoys a very rewarding career as a creative gold engraver, painter, woodcarver, and book illustrator. He loves to paint mythological images to educate people on the history of the Tsimshian nation and the many stories passed down through his ancestors. His greatest passion however is to spiritually represent and bond individuals together through the use of native Life Crest symbols.

The Tsimshian believe the Hummingbird to be a joyful messenger and mysterious traveler. If he appears during a time of great sorrow and pain, healing will soon follow. He also symbolizes the fragility of nature and all living things. This symbol is often used in gifts between lovers, for wedding rings, on a bracelet or any piece of jewellery - it says you are wished joy, healing and love. The Hummingbird also tells the receiver they bring joy to the giver's life.
datalanguage.description_short: Kitchen embroidered tea towel. Hummingbird design. White and blue. 100% cotton. Embroidered in Canada. MADE WHERE?

datalanguage.name: Bill Helin Raven Apron
datalanguage.description:
Tsimshian native artist Bill Helin enjoys a very rewarding career as a creative gold engraver, painter, woodcarver, and book illustrator. He loves to paint mythological images to educate people on the history of the Tsimshian nation and the many stories passed down through his ancestors. His greatest passion however is to spiritually represent and bond individuals together through the use of native Life Crest symbols.

Mischievous and curious the Raven is the cultural focus of the Native Northwest Coast People. He symbolizes creation, knowledge, prestige as well as the complexity of nature and the subtlety of truth.

datalanguage.name: Andrew Williams Hummingbird Oven Mitt
datalanguage.description:
Andrew Williams was born in 1964 in Haida Gwaii. He is a carver of argillite, silver and gold as well as a graphic designer. He is part of the Raven clan in the Old Masset on Haida Gwaii. His work is a blend of traditional and contemporary art and shows his passion for his Haida Ancestory and the "old stories".

A literal symbol of joy, this tiny bird represents friendship and intelligence.  He is also a symbol of good luck.

datalanguage.name: Andrew Williams Octopus Oven Mitt
datalanguage.description:
Andrew Williams was born in 1964 in Haida Gwaii. He is a carver of argillite, silver and gold as well as a graphic designer. He is part of the Raven clan in the Old Masset on Haida Gwaii. His work is a blend of traditional and contemporary art and shows his passion for his Haida Ancestory and the "old stories".

Octopus represents transformation. Commonly referred to as Devilfish, the Octopus is a secondary crest figure but is central to many myths along the Northwest Coast. The Octopus has close links to shamanism and transformation symbolism due to its ability to change colour and shape.
datalanguage.description_short: Kitchen oven mitt. Octopus design. Black and blue. 100% cotton. Made in Canada.

datalanguage.meta_description: Kitchen apron. "Children of the Raven" design. Black, red and white. Dimensions: 24" x 12". 100% cotton. Made in Canada.
datalanguage.meta_keywords: Bill Reid "Children of the Raven" Apron, Aprons, SKU: 51-51-032, Bill, kitchen, cotton, apron, reid, childrenoftheraven, Compositions: Cotton,
datalanguage.meta_title: Bill Reid "Children of the Raven" Apron
datalanguage.name: Bill Reid "Children of the Raven" Apron
datalanguage.description:
William Ronald Reid, "Bill", sculptor (Victoria, Jan 12, 1920 - March 13, 1998). Bill Reid, an internationally renowned Haida artist  is often cited as one who has renewed and revived Northwest Coast Aboriginal arts on the contemporary art scene. Very talented in many techniques, he carved silver, gold, wood, argilite and bronze. He has published several editions of silk screening, has illustrated and collaborated on numerous books.

He received an honorary doctorate from the University of British Columbia in 1976, the Molson Prize in 1977, and the National Aboriginal Achievement Award which is sponsored by the Canadian Foundation for  Aboriginal Art  in 1994. Bill Reid was a strong advocate for Aboriginal rights in Canada. He played a particularly active role in the battle to preserve the national and cultural history of South Moresby in Haida Gwaii.
datalanguage.description_short: Kitchen apron. "Children of the Raven" design. Black, red and white. Dimensions: 24" x 12". 100% cotton. Made in Canada.

William Ronald Reid, "Bill", sculptor (Victoria, Jan 12, 1920 - March 13, 1998). Bill Reid, an internationally renowned Haida artist  is often cited as one who has renewed and revived Northwest Coast Aboriginal arts on the contemporary art scene. Very talented in many techniques, he carved silver, gold, wood, argilite and bronze. He has published several editions of silk screening, has illustrated and collaborated on numerous books.

He received an honorary doctorate from the University of British Columbia in 1976, the Molson Prize in 1977, and the National Aboriginal Achievement Award which is sponsored by the Canadian Foundation for  Aboriginal Art  in 1994. Bill Reid was a strong advocate for Aboriginal rights in Canada. He played a particularly active role in the battle to preserve the national and cultural history of South Moresby in Haida Gwaii.
datalanguage.description_short: Kitchen oven mitt. Design of the "Children of the Raven". 100% cotton. Made in Canada.

datalanguage.description: As a Crow of the Tlingit tribe, Clifton Fred’s artistic sensibility reflects the views and achievements of his cultural ancestry. As he puts it “through our art I hope we can remind each other of who we were, what we did, and how we felt. If understanding our beginnings enable us to know our ends, then we may find that all cultures have the same origins and therefore the same destiny. Knowing this we can do nothing other than work together.”
datalanguage.description_short: Kitchen oven mitt. "Bear Box" design. 100% cotton. Made in Canada.

datalanguage.name: Connie Dickens Raven Oven Mitt
datalanguage.description: Located twenty miles below the Alaskan border is the Coast Tsimshian village of Lax Kw'alaams. Connie Dickens is a Raven of this village also known as Port Simpson. After graduating from high school in Prince Rupert where she was born and raised, Connie attended the Kitanmax School of Northwest Coast Native Art in Hazelton, B.C. for two years. On completion of the course, wood carving became the medium of choice. Once Connie and her husband Art had their three children, she decided to try and develop her drawing skills. Drawing has become the main focus of her artistic pursuits.
datalanguage.description_short: Kitchen oven mitt. Raven design. 100% cotton. Made in Canada.

datalanguage.description:
Born in Alert Bay  British Columbia in 1959 Corrine Hunt has been producing contemporary art that reflects the themes and traditions of her First Nations Kwakiutl and Tlingit heritage for more than 22 years. "I want to show how both the First Nations people and the art have evolved", she explains. Corrine has mentored First Nations and other artists and continues to be a strong and vocal supporter of the arts in British Columbia.

Namwayut "We are One".

datalanguage.description: Born in Alert Bay  British Columbia in 1959 Corrine Hunt has been producing contemporary art that reflects the themes and traditions of her First Nations Kwakiutl and Tlingit heritage for more than 22 years. "I want to show how both the First Nations people and the art have evolved", she explains. Corrine has mentored First Nations and other artists and continues to be a strong and vocal supporter of the arts in British Columbia.
datalanguage.description_short: Cheese knive and fork set with carved handles that are made of fine, lead free pewter. The blade and tongs are stainless steel and perfectly sized for your needs and enjoyment. Wash by hand with mild soap and water. Never place in dishwasher as the detergents are too corrosive for this fine metal. Made in Canada.

datalanguage.meta_description: Ensemble de couteau et fourchette à fromage avec les poignées sculptées en étain sans plomb. La lame et les dents sont en acier inoxydable et parfaitement dimen
datalanguage.meta_keywords: Corrine Hunt Sea to Sky Couteau à Fromage, Utensils, SKU: 00-06-915, , Composition: Étain,
datalanguage.meta_title: Corrine Hunt Sea to Sky Couteau à Fromage
datalanguage.name: Corrine Hunt Sea to Sky Couteau à Fromage
datalanguage.description_short: Ensemble de couteau et fourchette à fromage avec les poignées sculptées en étain sans plomb. La lame et les dents sont en acier inoxydable et parfaitement dimensionnés pour vos besoins et le plaisir. Laver à la main avec un savon doux et de l'eau. Ne jamais placer dans un lave-vaisselle comme les détergents sont trop corrosifs pour ce métal fin. Fait au canada.

datalanguage.description:
Born in Alert Bay  British Columbia in 1959 Corrine Hunt has been producing contemporary art that reflects the themes and traditions of her First Nations Kwakiutl and Tlingit heritage for more than 22 years. "I want to show how both the First Nations people and the art have evolved", she explains. Corrine has mentored First Nations and other artists and continues to be a strong and vocal supporter of the arts in British Columbia.

Namwayut "We are One".
datalanguage.description_short: Salad servers made of recycled glass, black. Made in Canada.

datalanguage.meta_keywords: Jim Charlie Tablier Raven Apron, Aprons, SKU: 52-52-618, kitchen, apron, raven, jim, charlie, Compositions: Cotton,
datalanguage.name: Jim Charlie Tablier Raven Apron
datalanguage.description: Jim Charlie was born in 1967 in North Vancouver, British Columbia. Jim Charlie is part of the Coast Salish Nation. He was educated in the histories and culture of the Salish peoples throughout his youth and studied under Salish carvers Floyd Joseph and Jacob Lewis as well as the renowned Gitksan artist Phil Janze. Charlie's work represents a variety of Northwest Coast legends, and is notable for its broad and accessible style.
datalanguage.description_short: Kitchen apron with Raven design. Dimensions: 24" x 12". 100% cotton. Made in Canada.

datalanguage.description: Klatle-Bhi (pronounced “Klath-Bay”) is an artist of Squamish and Kwakwaka’wakw ancestry. He grew up in the Kwakiutl culture of mask dancing, singing, and potlatching and has played a prominent role in the recent revival of the sea-going canoe journeys. Klatle-Bhi’s art is an expression of his personal and spiritual journey, as well as a reflection of his respective cultures.
datalanguage.description_short: Kitchen apron with Killer Whale design. 100% cotton.

datalanguage.description: Klatle-Bhi (pronounced “Klath-Bay”) is an artist of Squamish and Kwakwaka’wakw ancestry. He grew up in the Kwakiutl culture of mask dancing, singing, and potlatching and has played a prominent role in the recent revival of the sea-going canoe journeys. Klatle-Bhi’s art is an expression of his personal and spiritual journey, as well as a reflection of his respective cultures.
datalanguage.description_short: Kitchen oven mitt with the Killer Whale design. 100% cotton. Made in Canada.

datalanguage.meta_keywords: Corrine Hunt Sea to Sky Belt Buckle, Belts, SKU: 00-04-529, glass, corrine, hunt, recycled, seatosky, belt, buckle, Compositions: Recycled glass,
datalanguage.meta_title: Corrine Hunt Sea to Sky Belt Buckle
datalanguage.name: Corrine Hunt Sea to Sky Belt Buckle
datalanguage.description: Born in Alert Bay  British Columbia in 1959 Corrine Hunt has been producing contemporary art that reflects the themes and traditions of her First Nations Kwakiutl and Tlingit heritage for more than 22 years. "I want to show how both the First Nations people and the art have evolved", she explains. Corrine has mentored First Nations and other artists and continues to be a strong and vocal supporter of the arts in British Columbia.
datalanguage.description_short: Belt buckle from the Sea to Sky collection, made of recycled glass, black. Made in Canada.

datalanguage.meta_description: Bucket tote bag with Raven design made of flocked fabric. Made in Canada.
datalanguage.meta_keywords: Connie Dickens Raven Bucket Tote Bag, Bags & Purses, SKU: 52-52-414, bag, raven, connie, dickens, tote, flocked, bucket, Compositions: Fabric,
datalanguage.meta_title: Connie Dickens Raven Bucket Tote Bag
datalanguage.name: Connie Dickens Raven Bucket Tote Bag
datalanguage.description: Located twenty miles below the Alaskan border is the Coast Tsimshian village of Lax Kw'alaams. Connie Dickens is a Raven of this village also known as Port Simpson. After graduating from high school in Prince Rupert where she was born and raised, Connie attended the Kitanmax School of Northwest Coast Native Art in Hazelton, B.C. for two years. On completion of the course, wood carving became the medium of choice. Once Connie and her husband Art had their three children, she decided to try and develop her drawing skills. Drawing has become the main focus of her artistic pursuits.
datalanguage.description_short: Bucket tote bag with Raven design made of flocked fabric. Made in Canada.

datalanguage.name: Kelly Robinson Eagle Bucket Tote Bag
datalanguage.description: Born in 1981 in Nanaimo, British Columbia, Kelly Robinson's roots and family originate in Bella Coola, BC with descendants from both the Nuxalk and Nuu-chah-nulth nations. He was exposed to First Nations artwork from an early age and has always been interested in learning and refining the art- specifically the unique design forms of the Nuxalk.

datalanguage.description: Born in 1981 in Nanaimo, British Columbia, Kelly Robinson's roots and family originate in Bella Coola, BC with descendants from both the Nuxalk and Nuu-chah-nulth nations. He was exposed to First Nations artwork from an early age and has always been interested in learning and refining the art- specifically the unique design forms of the Nuxalk.

datalanguage.meta_keywords: Corrine Hunt Silk Inspiration Bangle, Bracelets, SKU: 00-07-730x3, silk, corrine, hunt, pewter, bangle, bracelet, inspiration, Compositions: Silk, Size: S, Size: M, Size: L, Navajo jewelry, Southwest jewelry
datalanguage.name: Corrine Hunt Silk Inspiration Bangle
datalanguage.description: Born in Alert Bay  British Columbia in 1959 Corrine Hunt has been producing contemporary art that reflects the themes and traditions of her First Nations Kwakiutl and Tlingit heritage for more than 22 years. "I want to show how both the First Nations people and the art have evolved", she explains. Corrine has mentored First Nations and other artists and continues to be a strong and vocal supporter of the arts in British Columbia.

datalanguage.name: Kelly Robinson Silk Inspiration Bangle
datalanguage.description: Born in 1981 in Nanaimo, British Columbia, Kelly Robinson's roots and family originate in Bella Coola, BC with descendants from both the Nuxalk and Nuu-chah-nulth nations. He was exposed to First Nations artwork from an early age and has always been interested in learning and refining the art- specifically the unique design forms of the Nuxalk.

datalanguage.name: Andrew Williams Octopus Bracelet
datalanguage.description: Born in 1964 in Haida Gwaii, Andrew Williams is a carver or argillite, silver and gold as well as a graphic designer. He is part of the Raven clan in the Old Masset on Haida Gwaii. His work is a blend of traditional and contemporary art and shows his passion for his Haida Ancestory and the "old stories".
datalanguage.description_short:

datalanguage.name: Andrew Williams Raven Bracelet
datalanguage.description: Tsimshian native artist Bill Helin enjoys a very rewarding career as a creative gold engraver, painter, woodcarver, and book illustrator. He loves to paint mythological images to educate people on the history of the Tsimshian nation and the many stories passed down through his ancestors. His greatest passion however is to spiritually represent and bond individuals together through the use of native Life Crest symbols.

datalanguage.name: Corrine Hunt Eagle Earrings
datalanguage.description: Born in Alert Bay  British Columbia in 1959 Corrine Hunt has been producing contemporary art that reflects the themes and traditions of her First Nations Kwakiutl and Tlingit heritage for more than 22 years. "I want to show how both the First Nations people and the art have evolved", she explains. Corrine has mentored First Nations and other artists and continues to be a strong and vocal supporter of the arts in British Columbia.

datalanguage.name: Kelly Robinson Hummingbird Bracelet
datalanguage.description: Born in 1981 in Nanaimo, British Columbia, Kelly Robinson's roots and family originate in Bella Coola, BC with descendants from both the Nuxalk and Nuu-chah-nulth nations. He was exposed to First Nations artwork from an early age and has always been interested in learning and refining the art- specifically the unique design forms of the Nuxalk.

datalanguage.name: Keith Tait Frog Box
datalanguage.description: Keith Tait was born into the Gitsan Nation at Kispiox in the province of British Columbia. He was trained in art and design at the Gitamaax School of northwest art at Ksan Village in Hazelton. Keith Tait’s graphic sensibility is reflected in the bold precision of his artwork. His designs provide a unique and natural expression of the Northwest Coast traditions of the Bella Coola region.
datalanguage.description_short: Frog designed box made of recycled glass. Made in Canada.

datalanguage.meta_keywords: Potlatch Bear Dish, Plates & Platters, SKU: 00-02-826, bear, dish, bowl, haida, potlatch, wood, ,
datalanguage.name: Potlatch Bear Dish
datalanguage.description: This bowl is a contemporary representation of the bowl and serving pieces used during the potlatches and feasts held by the native people of the Northwest Coast. The Bear is a symbol of earthly power and was sometimes used to indicate the authority of the chief. His short snout, large teeth and paws make him an unmistakable figure, representing a particularity great force and might.
datalanguage.description_short: Potlatch wooden dish beautifully carved and painted with the Bear design. Dimensions: 7". Made in Canada.

datalanguage.name: Potlatch Raven Bowl
datalanguage.description: This bowl is a contemporary representation of the bowl and serving pieces used during the potlatches and feasts held by the native people of the Northwest Coast. The Raven brought light to the world through his abilities as a trickster and his power to transform. The Eagle is generally seen as a symbol of power of knowledge, prestige, friendship and peace. The Eagle is one of the two main Haida crests, the other being the Raven.

Fait au Canada.

datalanguage.name: Bill Helin Eagle Coin Purse
datalanguage.description: Tsimshian native artist Bill Helin enjoys a very rewarding career as a creative gold engraver, painter, woodcarver, and book illustrator. He loves to paint mythological images to educate people on the history of the Tsimshian nation and the many stories passed down through his ancestors. His greatest passion however is to spiritually represent and bond individuals together through the use of native Life Crest symbols.
datalanguage.description_short: Embossed genuine deerskin coin purse with Bill Helin's Eagle design. Dimensions: 5" x 3.5". Available in Black Leather, Red Leather, Cherry Leather, Turquoise Leather or Walnut Leather. Deerskin Red or Deerskin Tan. Made in Canada.

Imprimé sur un papier de coton à 100%, ce giclé d'édition limitée comprend un passe-partout cœur noir sans acide et un endos. Emballée individuellement dans un sac transparent. Biographie de l'artiste à l'endos. Pour une grandeur personnalisée, s'il vous plaît communiquez avec nous.

Fait au Canada.
